ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was, needless to say, the largest research project and paper I've worked on. I learned so much about what it means to do research in English and I gained a much deeper connection to the novels I wrote about.

Writing a senior essay for the English major was a deeply rewarding experience. It was intense and (at times) stressful, but it also reminded me what a joy it is to have ample time and space to sit with a primary text of interest and explore its meanings/forms!! I learned a lot about writing critically, doing literary research, close reading, synthesizing ideas, contextualizing a text in the broader critical conversation about it, etc... of course. But I also learned a lot about budgeting time for such a big project, managing stress about a senior essay, and the revision process.
Professor Mukhopadhyay helped me to develop an argument about my chosen novels and colonial logics of order.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ultimately your experience working on a thesis depends so much on who your advisor is. I feel lucky to have had a brilliant and supportive advisor. The weekly meetings were definitely helpful in making the experience less isolated and more communal. A lot of students didn't show up for these meetings, though, and I would have liked to have spent more time hearing about other people's projects and research methods.

I loved working closely with my advisor, Professor Mukhopadhyay. She is really so brilliant, amazing, and reassuring! This senior essay would not have been possible without her extensive support. Lukas, who helped lead the senior essay cohort meetings, was also very responsive and supportive. He read through last minute drafts, provided detailed edits, and was generally very calming!

There could have been some more centralized guidance from the english dept itself outside of meetings with Lukas. Some kind of rubric/formatting expectations would have been nice. Also younger students in the English department should be given more guidance on the process of choosing an advisor/starting the project because I had to learn how to start thinking about my senior thesis mostly by word of mouth and guidance from older friends. Otherwise, working with Professor Mukhopadhyay was absolutely wonderful. She is a brilliant and receptive advisor and her expertise in the subject area was evident. She has been an invaluable mentor and resource, working with her has been one of the highlights of my time at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The library check-out process was a little tricky due to the pandemic. Otherwise, I felt that the seminar and advisory format over Zoom was fine. Writing retreats over Zoom are kind of weird - it is more convenient, but it is hard to ignore distractions/feel fully immersed in the writing space virtually!
I'm not a fan of virtual writing retreats, also some of the meetings we had with Lukas could have been emails.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Writing a senior essay isn't for everyone, and it also is not a requirement of the major, but this was a wonderful way to give closure to my much-loved time with the English department at Yale. I really loved the joy and luxury of spending extensive time with my work of interest, and I LOVED working closely with my advisor. I also received SO MUCH feedback on every draft that I submitted; I really feel that I grew in this last semester with regards to the kind of writer, editor, and organizational thinker that I am.
Yes! It's great to work on independent projects.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Only virtual meetings and writing retreats with the senior essay cohort and my senior essay advisor!
